G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Under G.L. c. 186, § 14, every residential tenancy in Massachusetts includes a covenant of quiet enjoyment, which prohibits a landlord from directly or indirectly interfering with the tenant’s right to use and enjoy the leased premises.

G.L. c. 186.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant has been Plaintiff’s landlord within the meaning of Massachusetts General Laws (“G.L.”) c. 186.

G.L. c. 218, \u00a7\u00a7 19 & 21.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 21, and G.L. c. 185C, because the claims arise from a residential tenancy in Worcester County and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 185C.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction pursuant to G.L. c. 218, §§ 19 & 21, and G.L. c. 185C, because the claims arise from a residential tenancy in Worcester County and the amount in controversy is within the jurisdictional limits of this Court.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 2.proposition: Venue is proper in Worcester District Court because the Premises that are the subject of this action are located in Worcester, Massachusetts. See G.L. c. 223, § 2.

105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq..proposition: The presence of mouse droppings and rodent activity in the kitchen of a residential dwelling unit is a condition that renders the premises in violation of the Massachusetts State Sanitary Code, 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq., including but not limited to 105 C.M.R. 410.550 (rodent and insect infestation) and 105 C.M.R. 410.100 (owner’s responsibility to maintain the dwelling free from violations).

105 C.M.R. 410.550.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as owner and landlord, has had the duty to maintain the Premises, including Plaintiff’s Apartment, in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to remedy conditions that materially impair the health, safety, or well-being of occupants, including rodent infestations. See 105 C.M.R. 410.100, 410.550.

105 C.M.R. 410.100.proposition: At all relevant times, Defendant, as owner and landlord, has had the duty to maintain the Premises, including Plaintiff’s Apartment, in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to remedy conditions that materially impair the health, safety, or well-being of occupants, including rodent infestations. See 105 C.M.R. 410.100, 410.550.

G.L. c. 111, \u00a7\u00a7 127A\u2013127L.proposition: Defendant, as Plaintiff’s landlord, had a non-delegable duty to maintain the Apartment and building in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to remedy rodent infestations that affect tenants’ health, safety, and use of the premises. See *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.

*Hemmings v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 30 Mass..raw_text: *Hemmings v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 561 (1991)
*Hemmings v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 30 Mass..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that serious and ongoing violations of the State Sanitary Code, or conditions that materially impair the health or safety of tenants, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
*Hemmings v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 30 Mass..support_reasoning: This opinion concerns criminal gambling indictments involving video poker machines and the interpretation of Massachusetts gaming and amusement-device statutes. It does not involve landlord-tenant law, the State Sanitary Code, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it cannot be used as authority for the proposition that serious sanitary code violations or dangerous conditions constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Hemmings v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 30 Mass..relevant_excerpt: The provided text of *Hemmings v. Mass. Port Auth.*, 30 Mass. App. Ct. 561 (1991), contains no discussion of landlord-tenant relationships, the State Sanitary Code, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment; it instead addresses whether video poker machines are gambling devices and the sufficiency of evidence before a grand jury.

*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that serious and ongoing violations of the State Sanitary Code, or conditions that materially impair the health or safety of tenants, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion squarely holds that a landlord’s failure to provide heat in violation of the State Sanitary Code “seriously impairs” the premises and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. It treats the lack of heat—a serious health and safety condition governed by the Sanitary Code—as sufficient to trigger quiet enjoyment liability regardless of the landlord’s intent or financial inability, thus supporting the proposition that serious, ongoing code violations or health/safety-impairing conditions can breach quiet enjoyment.
*Lowery v. Robinson*, 13 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A landlord’s failure to provide heat during the heating season (see State Sanitary Code, 105 Code Mass. Regs. §§ 410.201, 410.750 [B] [1980]) seriously ‘impair[s] the character and value of the leased premises’ … and constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. … It is not necessary to recovery that the landlord intended to violate the covenant. Rather ‘the landlord’s conduct, and not his intentions, is controlling.’”

*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.raw_text: *Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Mass. 273 (1994)
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that serious and ongoing violations of the State Sanitary Code, or conditions that materially impair the health or safety of tenants, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.support_reasoning: The case recognizes that serious interference with tenants’ use of premises (here, pervasive criminal/drug activity in common areas) can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment, but it does not ground that conclusion in State Sanitary Code violations or health/safety code-based conditions. The opinion addresses quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14 in terms of landlord acts/omissions and serious interference, not in terms of sanitary code or habitability standards; indeed, the court expressly limits the warranty of habitability to physical defects and does not tie quiet enjoyment to State Sanitary Code violations. Thus it does not support the specific proposition that serious and ongoing State Sanitary Code violations or similar health/safety conditions have long been recognized as a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Doe v. New Bedford Hous. Auth.*, 417 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The covenant of quiet enjoyment protects a tenant’s right to freedom from serious interference with his tenancy — acts or omissions that impair the character and value of the leasehold… In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises.”

*Gomes v. Haverhill*, 79 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: *Gomes v. Haverhill*, 79 Mass. App. Ct. 1124 (2011) (Rule 1:28 decision)
*Gomes v. Haverhill*, 79 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Massachusetts courts have long recognized that serious and ongoing violations of the State Sanitary Code, or conditions that materially impair the health or safety of tenants, can constitute a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See, e.g.:
*Gomes v. Haverhill*, 79 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The provided opinion text in *Gomes v. Haverhill* (actually captioned *Novastar Mortgage, Inc. v. Saffran* in the excerpt) is a very short Rule 1:28 decision that only reverses and remands in light of *U.S. Bank Nat’l Ass’n v. Ibanez*. It does not mention the State Sanitary Code, tenant health or safety conditions, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment, nor does it discuss landlord‑tenant habitability issues at all. Therefore, it does not support the stated proposition about sanitary code violations constituting a breach of quiet enjoyment.
*Gomes v. Haverhill*, 79 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: The decision of the Appellate Division is reversed and a new decision is to enter reversing the judgment of the District Court and remanding the case to that court for a new determination in light of the principles discussed in U.S. Bank Natl. Assn. v. Ibanez, 458 Mass. 637 (2011).

*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.proposition: Defendant, as Plaintiff’s landlord, had a non-delegable duty to maintain the Apartment and building in compliance with the State Sanitary Code and to remedy rodent infestations that affect tenants’ health, safety, and use of the premises. See *Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379 Mass. 196 (1979); G.L. c. 111, §§ 127A–127L; 105 C.M.R. 410.000 et seq.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the landlord’s implied warranty of habitability and its connection to State Sanitary Code violations, but it does not frame that duty as a “non-delegable duty” nor does it involve or discuss rodent infestations. The case holds that a landlord is strictly liable in contract for rent abatement when premises do not comply with the Sanitary Code (e.g., lack of heat and hot water), independent of fault or reasonable repair efforts. Using this case specifically as authority for a non-delegable duty to remedy rodent infestations overstates and mischaracterizes its holding.
*Berman & Sons, Inc. v. Jefferson*, 379.relevant_excerpt: “In the latter instance, the landlord must comply at least with minimum standards prescribed by the State building and sanitary codes. Whether the scope of the warranty is broader is an open question… A dwelling afflicted with a substantial Sanitary Code violation is not habitable. … The State Sanitary Code, not such usage, provides the proper yardstick for measuring the landlord’s conduct. The Hemingway court removed the landlord’s duties under the Code from the realm of private ordering. Those duties cannot be waived, bargained away, or qualified by customary practice.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Defendant’s failure to act reasonably to correct the rodent infestation, and his refusal to authorize appropriate extermination despite ongoing evidence of droppings and continued infestation, constitutes an “indirect” interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: Blackett does not involve rodents or G.L. c. 186, § 14 directly, but it clearly articulates the broader principle that a landlord breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment when a substantial interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, failed to do, or permitted to be done, and the landlord had the ability to control and correct the condition but did not do so. That reasoning can be applied by analogy to a landlord’s failure to take reasonable steps to abate a rodent infestation, making Blackett indirect but supportive authority for the proposition of "indirect" interference through inaction.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done... Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable.

*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).proposition: Defendant’s failure to act reasonably to correct the rodent infestation, and his refusal to authorize appropriate extermination despite ongoing evidence of droppings and continued infestation, constitutes an “indirect” interference with Plaintiff’s quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (1977); *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).support_reasoning: The case does interpret G.L. c. 186, § 14 to cover a landlord’s reckless, indirect interference with a tenant’s quiet enjoyment, and it expressly relies on Blackett’s concept of indirect interference. However, the actual interference in Simon is repeated flooding/sewage, not a rodent infestation or refusal to authorize extermination; rodents are mentioned only as background and are not the basis of the § 14 holding. Thus, Simon supports the broader idea that reckless inaction creating unsanitary conditions can be an indirect interference, but it does not specifically stand for the proposition about rodent infestation and extermination efforts.
*Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982).relevant_excerpt: “When § 14 was first enacted, both categories of prohibited conduct — failure to provide services and interference with quiet enjoyment — were modified by the words ‘willfully or intentionally.’… In 1973, the statute was rewritten… landlords were now liable for ‘directly or indirectly’ interfering with tenants’ quiet enjoyment of leased premises. One natural inference from this amendment is that the Legislature meant to abrogate the requirement of specific intent to disturb quiet enjoyment.… [T]he statute covers, at the least, reckless conduct such as Gem’s.… Gem is liable to Solomon under G. L. c. 186, § 14 because it… permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment.”

*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to remedy conditions that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises for residential use, after notice and over a period of time, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782 (1994); *Doyle v. Norwood Realty, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 1004 (1988).
*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.support_reasoning: The opinion is focused on what level of fault is required to establish a violation of the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14. In doing so, the court expressly reaffirms that a landlord’s negligent failure to repair known defects or conditions in leased premises that foreseeably interfere with the tenant’s use constitutes a breach of quiet enjoyment, citing Simon, Cruz, and related cases. Although the facts concern lead paint, the court’s general articulation of § 14 liability squarely supports the broader proposition about failure to remedy materially impairing residential conditions after notice.
*Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (199.relevant_excerpt: “We noted that a landlord’s failure ‘to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.’ See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord….”

*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to remedy conditions that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises for residential use, after notice and over a period of time, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782 (1994); *Doyle v. Norwood Realty, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 1004 (1988).
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.support_reasoning: The court expressly applies G.L. c. 186, § 14 and the covenant of quiet enjoyment to a landlord’s failure, over a period of time and after notice, to correct numerous serious sanitary, building, and fire code violations that substantially impaired the premises’ value as a dwelling. It holds that such omissions, despite attempted but ineffectual repairs, constitute a violation of § 14 because they foreseeably and substantially impaired the value of the leased premises as a dwelling. This directly supports the proposition that failure to remedy materially impairing conditions after notice and over time breaches the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 78.relevant_excerpt: “Cruz Management had notice of numerous sanitary, building and fire code violations in the apartment leased by Thomas. It was wholly foreseeable (in fact, it was inevitable) that the failure adequately to correct these violations, which included inadequate heat and hot water and a serious infestation of vermin, would impair substantially the value of the leased premises as a dwelling place for Thomas and her family. On the facts found by the judge a violation of § 14 has been shown.”

*Doyle v. Norwood Realty, Inc.*, 26 Mass.raw_text: *Doyle v. Norwood Realty, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 1004 (1988)
*Doyle v. Norwood Realty, Inc.*, 26 Mass.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a landlord’s failure to remedy conditions that materially impair the character and value of the leased premises for residential use, after notice and over a period of time, constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91 (1982); *Al Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847 (1997); *Cruz Mgmt. Co. v. Thomas*, 417 Mass. 782 (1994); *Doyle v. Norwood Realty, Inc.*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 1004 (1988).
*Doyle v. Norwood Realty, Inc.*, 26 Mass.support_reasoning: The provided opinion is a Massachusetts divorce and property-division decision that addresses alimony, equitable distribution, and the propriety of conveying the marital home in lieu of alimony. It does not discuss landlord–tenant law, residential conditions, habitability, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Accordingly, it cannot serve as authority for the proposition that a landlord’s failure to remedy materially impairing conditions constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment.
*Doyle v. Norwood Realty, Inc.*, 26 Mass.relevant_excerpt: General Laws c. 208, § 34, confers broad discretion on a judge in awarding alimony and making equitable property divisions. … The purpose of an award of alimony is to provide economic support to a dependent spouse. … The purpose of a property division is to recognize and equitably recompense the parties’ respective contributions to the marital partnership. … An order to convey property in lieu of alimony past, present, and future is, in our opinion, inappropriate under most circumstances and constitutes an abuse of discretion here.
